[[University of Oxford]] | doctoral_advisor = [[John Kingman]] | known_for = }} '''Peter Gavin Hall''' [[Australian Academy of Science|FAA]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] [[Order of Australia|AO]] (born 20 November 1951) is an [[Australia]]n researcher in [[probability theory]] and [[mathematical statistics]]. He earned his Doctorate at the University of Oxford in 1976. ==Biography== Dr. Hall was born to [[radiophysics]] and [[radio astronomy]] pioneer [[Ruby Payne-Scott]] and telephone technician William Holman Hall. His younger sister is artistic photographer and sculptor, [[Fiona Margaret Hall]]. Hall is an author in probability and statistics. [[Mathscinet]] lists him with more than 500 publications as of January 2008. He has made contributions to nonparametric statistics, in particular for curve estimation and resampling: the bootstrap method, smoothing, density estimation, and bandwidth selection. He has worked on numerous applications across fields of economics, engineering, physical science and biological science. Hall has also made contributions to surface roughness measurement using fractals. In probability theory he has made many contributions to limit theory, spatial processes and [[stochastic geometry]]. His paper "Theoretical comparison of bootstrap confidence intervals" (Annals of Statistics, 1988) has been reprinted in the ''Breakthroughs in Statistics'' collection. Professor Hall is currently an [[ARC Laureate Fellow]] at the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, [[University of Melbourne]],http://www.arc.gov.au/media/fl11/pdf/Peter_Hall_bio.pdf and also has a joint appointment at [[University of California Davis]].{{cite web | title=UCDavis - History of the Department of Statistics | url=http://anson.ucdavis.edu/about/history | accessdate= 4 March 2011}}
